title: 113_s2399
content: The "Native Voting Rights Act of 2014" is also known as the Act. It addresses tribal identification and actions for disparities in polling place availability. Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act is amended to allow tribal identification documents to be treated as valid forms of identification for voting purposes. The Attorney General may take actions, including against States, in the name of the United States. The Attorney General can take legal actions, including against States, for declaratory judgment or injunctive relief if there is a disparity in voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe compared to non-members. Injunctive relief may involve increasing polling place availability. District courts of the United States have jurisdiction over such actions. The district courts of the United States have jurisdiction over legal actions regarding disparities in voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe. Such actions may involve increasing polling place availability and can be appealed to the Supreme Court. The district courts have jurisdiction over legal actions related to disparities in voting opportunities for members of an Indian tribe, which can be expedited. There is a presumption that such disparities may deny or limit the voting rights of US citizens based on race or color. An aggrieved person can bring an action despite certain provisions, with the possibility of appeal to the Supreme Court. PROTECTIONS RELATING TO POLLING PLACES ON INDIAN RESERVATIONS. Section 4 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to include protections for Indian reservations, requiring approval for activities like eliminating polling places or moving them further away. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations, requiring approval for actions like moving polling places further away or eliminating in-person voting on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions such as designating an Indian reservation as a permanent absentee voting location, removing early voting opportunities, and decreasing the number of days or hours that voting locations are open on an Indian reservation. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for actions such as changing voting dates or locations on reservations. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for activities described in subsection (g) of section 4 after November 1, 1972, and by updating terminology to include "procedure, or activity". The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to protect Indian reservations by requiring approval for activities on reservations after November 1, 1972. Section 8 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow the Attorney General to authorize Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations, as defined under section 203, upon receiving a request from a tribal organization. The Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to allow Federal observers for elections on Indian reservations upon receiving a complaint and request from a tribal organization. SEC. 5 amends the Voting Rights Act of 1965 regarding the termination of election observers. It specifies the conditions under which observers appointed under subsection (b) of section 8 will cease their duties. SEC. 6 provides definitions. SEC. 6 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 amends definitions related to Indian tribes and tribal organizations, specifying the meanings of terms like 'Indian tribe' and 'tribal organization' as defined in relevant acts. SEC. 7 of the Voting Rights Act of 1965 is amended to update bilingual election requirements and the definition of Indian reservation. It changes the year from 1990 to 2010 and updates language requirements for Alaskan natives and American Indians. The Attorney General must release reports of Federal election observers within 6 months. The Attorney General should consult with tribal organizations annually on voting issues for Indian tribes.
